section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: The model organism Caenorhabditis elegans is used in a variety of applications ranging from fundamental biological studies, to drug screening, to disease modeling, and to space-biology investigations.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: These applications rely on conducting whole-organism phenotypic assays involving animal behavior and locomotion.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: In this study, we report a 3D printed compact imaging platform (CIP) that is integrated with a smart-device camera for the whole-organism phenotyping of C. elegans.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: The CIP has no external optical elements and does not require mechanical focusing, simplifying the optical configuration.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: The small footprint of the system powered with a standard USB provides capabilities ranging from plug-and-play, to parallel operation, and to housing it in incubators for temperature control.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: We demonstrate on Earth the compatibility of the CIP with different C. elegans substrates, including agar plates, liquid droplets on glass slides and microfluidic chips.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: We validate the system with behavioral and thrashing assays and show that the phenotypic readouts are in good agreement with the literature data.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: We conduct a pilot study with mutants and show that the phenotypic data collected from the CIP distinguishes these mutants.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: Finally, we discuss how the simplicity and versatility offered by CIP makes it amenable to future C. elegans investigations on the International Space Station, where science experiments are constrained by system size, payload weight and crew time.

section_heading: ABSTRACT
text: Overall, the compactness, portability and ease-of-use makes the CIP desirable for research and educational outreach applications on Earth and in space.

section_heading: INTRODUCTION
text: In this study, we report a small foot-print smart-device imaging system called Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) that can acquire videos of C. elegans in agar plates, liquid droplets on a glass slide and microfluidic devices.

section_heading: INTRODUCTION

section_heading: INTRODUCTION

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Design considerations such as light weight, compactness and low power consumption are not only relevant for Earth-based C. elegans applications, but become essential for spaceflight studies.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: For example, the ISS is a closed environment with limited workspace for conducting experimental investigations; moreover, payload size and weight become crucial factors dictating whether an experiment should be launched.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Considering these needs, we designed and built a compact imaging platform (CIP).As shown in Figure 1, CIP is a small unit with length L = 7.5 , width W = 4.5 and height, H = 5.5 , occupying a footprint area of ≈34 in 2 and weighing ≈ 700 g.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The footprint is primarily determined by the need to accommodate the smartphone system, a fan for temperature control and the C. elegans substrate.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The mechanical design of the CIP is simple.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: It consists of two sections made from Polyamide 12 nylon material and printed using a multi-jet fusion 3D printer (HUBS, Chicago, IL, USA).The two sections are connected by hinges that allows their opening and closing (Figure 1a).The top section houses the iPod Touch camera (Apple Inc, Cupertino, CA, USA), and the bottom section houses the C. elegans substrate, 6500 k pure white LED lights (Power Practical Inc., Salt Lake City, UT, USA) and a 6000-rpm cooling fan (Wathai, China) (Figure 1b).Thin rectangular slots of 20 mm × 2 mm are provided on the top and bottom sections, acting as air vents to achieve thermal equilibrium when the CIP is placed in a temperature-controlled environment.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The thermal management system of the CIP works independently of the gravitational environment (ground or microgravity), due to active cooling and proper ventilation present in the system.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The imaging configuration of the CIP involves dark-field imaging of C. elegans samples by using a fixed-height illumination source and the iPod Touch camera.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The white LED lights in the bottom section are secured along the four walls, providing sidewise illumination to the specimen.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: No external optical elements or mechanical focusing is needed, making the design simple and user friendly.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Autofocusing is achieved using a 3rd-party app (FiLMiC Pro, Seattle, WA, USA) on the iPod Touch.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: This app also allows for adjustment of the magnification, field of view and frame rate of video acquisition.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: The fixed focal distance configuration gives a field of view of 15 mm × 23 mm to 38 mm × 68 mm depending on the optical 3x zoom available on the app.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Videos can be acquired at 1080p resolution with a frame rate of 3-30 fps, or time-lapse imaging can be performed with a delay ranging from 1-60 s.The mechanical design of the CIP is simple.

A smart-device camera such as the iPod Touch was chosen not only because of its ease of use on Earth, but also because of the specific advantages it provides for C. elegans experiments on the ISS.Unlike bulky conventional microscopy systems, it is a compact integrated imaging system that not only has optical elements for visualization, but also has a display (rather than a computer monitor) that allows the crew to inspect the animals and image quality.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Additionally, the iPod Touch has the capacity to store up to ≈250 GB worth of data, allowing for recording of up to ≈810,000 images which enables short-term (e.g., about 1800 movies of 1.5 min duration at 5 fps) and long-term behavioral assays (e.g., about 45 h at 5 fps).Image acquisition aspects such as autofocusing and video capture rate can be easily controlled using the installed app.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: Finally, conducting science experiments with specialized hardware on the ISS requires significant astronaut training; however, the crew is familiar with using smartphone devices and associated apps, making our smart-device approach crew-friendly for spaceflight experiments.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
text: A major advantage of the USB-powered CIP unit is that multiple units can be powered simultaneously using a multi-port hub without the need for individual wall chargers (Figure 1c).In addition, a programmable timer can be added that controls illumination intervals for long-term assays.

section_heading: Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components

Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: The small size of the CIP system allows it to be placed in a temperature-controlled incubator (Figure 1d).The design of the CIP makes it an enclosed system housing the C. elegans substrates, since the top section (containing the smart-device camera) is brought in contact with the bottom section during imaging.

section_heading: Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: The Initial trials showed that the main internal source of heat that the C. elegans substrates experience in the CIP is the radiant energy from the array of LED lights in the bottom section, which leads to an increase in temperature.

section_heading: Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: To address this issue, we created ventilation slots in the enclosure and installed a cooling fan at the left wall of the bottom section.

section_heading: Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: The forced convection from the cooling fan draws air from the ambient and distributes it through the ventilation slots.

section_heading: Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: To test the ability to control the temperature of the C. elegans substrate housed in the CIP, we conducted experiments in which the system was placed in the incubator along with two temperature data loggers-one in the LED chamber and the other on the microfluidic chip (Figure 3a).This experiment was conducted for three set temperatures of 15 • C, 20 • C, and 25 • C of the incubator, and measurements were taken for 24 h.As shown in Figure 3b,c, in less than 2 h, the temperature stabilizes for all three set temperature conditions, with a variation that is less than 0.5 • C. We also note that the CIP temperature is about 1 • C above the set temperature, due to local heating, which can be compensated by lowering the incubator temperature.

section_heading: Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
text: Thus, adequate temperature control can be achieved for C. elegans assays using the CIP.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: C. elegans has been an invaluable model organism for identifying the genetic basis of behavior and locomotion.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: There are many mutants that have been identified and classified based on automated image analysis, creating a behavioral database [44,45].Since the CIP can accommodate a variety of C. elegans substrates, it could be a useful tool to perform phenotypic studies with mutants.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: Here, we conduct a pilot study with a wild type and two mutants-unc-32(e189) and unc-79(e1068).Hierarchical clustering showed that these two mutants exist in a different phenotypic space in the behavioral database

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: [45], thus forming a testbed to evaluate the capabilities of the CIP.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: The unc-32 gene encodes the alpha subunit of a vacuolar ATP-ase (v-ATPase), an ATPdependent proton pump which functions to regulate neurotransmitter trafficking through synaptic vesicles and cell acidification [46].The unc-32(e189) mutation results in a reverse ventral coiling phenotype in the posterior region of the animals.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: Likewise, the unc-79 gene encodes a large cytosolic protein that is thought to regulate the post transcriptional processing of key voltage-gated sodium and calcium channels

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: [47,48].The unc-79(e1068) loss-of-function mutation results in a "fainting" phenotype that presents as repeating episodes of short bursts of normal movement that abruptly, but momentarily, stops [49].Such unc-79 mutants have also shown to be defective in their ability to transition from crawling to swimming [50], a subtle behavioral phenotype that was previously undetectable using classical behavioral metrics.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: The unc-32(e189) was previously characterized using plate-based methods and has not been assessed in any other environment.

section_heading: Phenotypic Studies with Mutants
text: We conducted thrashing and behavioral assays with the wild type and mutant animals to determine whether these assays, conducted with the CIP, could identify phenotypic differences.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Significant physiological changes occur during long-duration space travel, necessitating a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that induce these alterations

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: [53,54].Thus, model organisms such as C. elegans have been flown to the International Space Station (ISS) several times for space-biology investigations

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: [16][17][18][19][55][56][57][58][59][60].For spaceflight missions where payload size and weight are critical considerations, C. elegans experimental payloads offer a small-form factor and a significant reduction in weight compared with vertebrates.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Moreover, the fast reproductive cycle enables multi-generational studies to be conducted, providing an opportunity to explore physiological adaptations due to long-term habitation in space.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: These advantages and mutant resources make C. elegans a leading invertebrate animal model for spaceflight studies.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Despite several C. elegans studies on ISS, most of the spaceflight data is limited to changes in gene expression and fluorescent markers, and there is a dearth of wholeorganism phenotypic data.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: The major challenges for ISS investigations are the availability of microscopy hardware, access to crew time to conduct the studies, and payload weight/size requirements for imaging instrumentation.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Standard microscopes available on ISS are bulky, require significant crew training, have a limited field of view to do large-population imaging, rely on bulky monitors for crews to visualize samples, and data store/transfer needs are demanding.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: These limitations necessitate the need for custom-designed imaging hardware for gathering whole-animal phenotypic data to understand the effects of microgravity and radiation on C. elegans physiology.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: The compact imaging system developed in this study addresses the current limitations for phenotyping C. elegans on the ISS.The CIP has <1 kg payload requirement and occupies < 1 ft 3 .It is simple to use for crews and is a USB-powered plug-and-play device.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: The large field of view enables the interrogation of animal populations and provides a robust statistical evaluation of phenotypic data.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Sample visualization and data storage needs are integrated into a small form-factor smart-device.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Video data could be returned to Earth, and data analysis could be performed post-facto, thereby allowing the crew time to focus more on worm sample loading and basic payload handling.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Different C. elegans substrates can be integrated into the CIP based on science requirements, and the microfluidic chips are particularly appealing due to their enclosed configuration that allows the maintaining of a sterile environment and efficient fluid handling.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: Nematode sample preparation usually occurs on Earth, with worm culture bags being flown to the ISS, where the crew extracts samples and injects into the microfluidic chips.

section_heading: Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
text: The authors have recently flown to the ISS micropillar-based microfluidic devices for muscle strength measurements in C. elegans [20], and the CIP is a valuable addition to the imaging needs on the ISS.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: In this study, we report a compact imaging platform and successfully demonstrated that it can be used to acquire whole-organism phenotypic data using a variety of C. elegans substrates.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: We show that good temperature control can be achieved for assays, and that multiple CIP units can be used if needed to conduct parallel experiments.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: The videos acquired are compatible for analysis with established software tools.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: The C. elegans community continues to develop a variety of open-source image analysis tools [61] that could be potentially used to analyze images acquired from the CIP to increase the depth of phenotyping.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: The hardware of CIP as demonstrated here could be further improved.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: In addition to the smart-device camera, additional high-magnification optics could be integrated to provide higher-resolution images to pursue deep phenotyping, including access to organlevel information.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: Although we used the iPod Touch in this study, the 3D-printed imaging station concept can be extended to other low-cost cameras (e.g., Arducam series), along with Raspberry Pi integration.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: Opportunities exist to integrate additional hardware elements to study animal response to stimuli such as light, temperature and electric fields, which will broaden the types of assays that can be conducted.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: With advances in computation and artificial intelligence, apps could be custom-designed to integrate with a smart-device that allows real-time image analysis, storage of assay metadata and data visualization.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: In summary, the CIP is a simple, versatile, low-cost and small-footprint phenotyping tool for C. elegans assays, that could be deployed in research and educational settings on Earth in its current form.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: The CIP also presents a proof of concept for future setups for space biology research and could be adapted for ISS-compatible hardware.

section_heading: CONCLUSION
text: In the future, the system needs to undergo thorough ISS certification in terms of flammability, materials, off-gassing, electromagnetic interface, etc., as the assessment of multiple factors like safety, system reliability and long-term storage for equipment performance is necessary.

section_heading: METHODS
text: Animals were cultured in 60 mm nematode growth medium (NGM) petri plates with 150-200 µL E. Coli OP50 at 20 • C. Synchronized animals at day 5 from hatching were used in all the assays performed.

section_heading: METHODS
text: For this paper, the strains used were wild-type Bristol (N2), CB189 unc-32(e189) III., and CB1068 unc-79(e1086) III.

section_heading: Plate assay.
text: Twenty-four age-synced animals were transferred to 35 mm nematode growth medium (NGM) petri plates.

section_heading: Plate assay.
text: The plates were seeded 12 h prior to animal transfer so that the bacteria lawn was fresh and thin to obtain good quality contrast between animals and background.

text: Animals were loaded inside the chip using a 1 mL syringe connected with a 0.032" ID Tygon tubing (Cole-Parmer, Vernon Hills, IL, USA) with a stainless-steel coupler tube (Instech Labs, FL).Synchronized animals in an NGM plate were flooded with liquid NGM and then transferred to an empty plate.
